hints.title: Tensorization of LSI
hints.content:
851: :label: thm-tensorization
852: 
853: If each single-particle kernel $K_i$ satisfies an LSI with constant $C_i$, then the product kernel $K = \bigotimes_{i=1}^N K_i$ satisfies an LSI with constant:
854: 
855: $$
856: C_{\text{product}} = \max_{i=1, \ldots, N} C_i
hints.raw_directive:
848: where $\Psi_{\text{kin}}^{(i)}$ is the single-particle kinetic evolution.
849: 
850: :::{prf:theorem} Tensorization of LSI
851: :label: thm-tensorization
852: 
853: If each single-particle kernel $K_i$ satisfies an LSI with constant $C_i$, then the product kernel $K = \bigotimes_{i=1}^N K_i$ satisfies an LSI with constant:
854: 
855: $$
856: C_{\text{product}} = \max_{i=1, \ldots, N} C_i
857: $$

hints.label: proof-tensorization
hints.content:
861: :::{prf:proof}
862: :label: proof-tensorization
863: This is a classical result. For the product measure $\pi = \bigotimes_{i=1}^N \pi_i$ and function $f(x_1, \ldots, x_N)$:
864: 
865: $$
866: \text{Ent}_\pi(f^2) \le \sum_{i=1}^N \mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\text{Ent}_{\pi_i}(f^2 | x_1, \ldots, x_{i-1}, x_{i+1}, \ldots, x_N)\right]
867: $$
868: 
869: Each conditional entropy satisfies the single-particle LSI:
870: 
871: $$
872: \text{Ent}_{\pi_i}(f^2 | \cdots) \le C_i \mathcal{E}_i(f, f | \cdots)
873: $$
874: 
875: Summing over $i$ and taking $C = \max_i C_i$:
876: 
877: $$
878: \text{Ent}_\pi(f^2) \le C \sum_{i=1}^N \mathcal{E}_i(f, f) = C \mathcal{E}_{\text{product}}(f, f)

hints.label: cor-n-particle-kinetic-lsi
hints.title: LSI for N-Particle Kinetic Operator
hints.content:
884: :label: cor-n-particle-kinetic-lsi
885: 
886: The N-particle kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}^{\otimes N}$ satisfies a discrete-time LSI with the **same constant** as the single-particle operator:
887: 
888: $$
889: C_{\text{LSI}}^{\text{kin}, N}(\tau) = C_{\text{LSI}}^{\text{kin}}(\tau)

883: :::{prf:corollary} LSI for N-Particle Kinetic Operator
884: :label: cor-n-particle-kinetic-lsi
885: 
886: The N-particle kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}^{\otimes N}$ satisfies a discrete-time LSI with the **same constant** as the single-particle operator:
887: 
888: $$
889: C_{\text{LSI}}^{\text{kin}, N}(\tau) = C_{\text{LSI}}^{\text{kin}}(\tau)
